Inoculation and Vaccination of All Ranks completed.
Letter from Officer Commanding Unit to A.A.G. Military District No.1 LONDON ONTARIO stating Unit complete in every respect and prepared to proceed Overseas immediately.
STRENGTH OF UNIT UNCHANGED THROUGHOUT MONTH.
Letter received from A.A.G. No.1 Mil. List. warning Unit to be in readiness to proceed Overseas at an early date.
Field Day held by Officers and Men of Unit at Western University Campus LONDON ONTARIO.
Instructions received from A.A.G. No.1 Mil. Dist. that Unit leave LONDON ONT. at 12.20 P.M. August 18th/1916 via G.T.R.
Inspection of Unit by G.O.C. No.1 Military District and A.D.M.S. No.1 Military District.

1 Recruit taken on the Strength.

Complete Unit comprising Lt. Col. E. SEABORN Major C.E. BROWN Major J.C. WILSON Captains J.S. HUDSON A. TURNER E.H. YOUNG J. MORIARTY E. BICE A.E. FRALEIGH R.H. HENDERSON C.L. DOUGLAS C.P. JENTO G.M. BROCK and Lieut. J.A. DICKIE and 118 OTHER RANKS entrained at Grand Trunk Railway Station.
Unit arrived
Unit embarked on H.M.T. 2810 (Olympic)
Lt. Colonel E. SEABORN appointed Principal Medical Officer of the ship.
Troop Hospital on board taken over by Unit commenced treatment of all causes of sickness which developed and continued same throughout voyage.
1 Other Rank of Unit transferred to Shore Hospital HALIFAX seriously ill.
Inspection of Troops and Ship by H.R.H. the Duke of Connaught
Ship proceeded from Halifax.
Unit disembarked
Unit entrained for SHORNCLIFFE.
Unit arrived at SHORNCLIFFE Station and proceeded to camp.
Unit arrived at Canvas Camp St. Martin’s Plain SHORNCLIFFE KENT.
Unit attached to No.8 Canadian Stationary Hospital St. Martin’s Plain for Quarters and Rations.
One Casualty having occurred En Route Strength at this date was - OFFICERs-14. OTHER RANKS-117.

Letter received from A.D.M.S. Canadian Training Division SHORNCLIFFE directing that Lt.Colonel E. SEABORN two Medical Officers Quartermaster and 35 Other Ranks report to D.A.D.M.S. Canadians SEAFORD for the purpose of taking over Raven’s Croft Military Hospital.
Lt. Colonel E. SEABORN appointed Principal Medical Officer of the ship.
Lt. Colonel E. SEABORN appointed Principal Medical Officer of the ship.
Details as above arrived at SEAFORD Station and marched to CHYNGTON CAMP (1 Mile East).
Unit attached to 103rd Battalion C.E.F. for Quarters and Rations.
1 Other Rank recalled from Command.

Raven’s Croft Military Hospital taken over through Board of Survey from Imperial authorities and established as Headquarters of Unit. Bed capacity approximately 100. About 75 Imperial patients in Hospital at time of taking over were treated until their recovery or transfer to Imperial Hospitals. Chyngton Camp in its earliest stages as a Canadian Camp at this date about three Battalions being quartered there in hutments. Raven’s Croft Hospital a School building but occupied by the R.A.M.C. as a Military Hospital since 1914.
1 Other Rank recalled from Command.
2 Other Ranks recalled from Command.
Captain C.P. JENTO and 1 Other Rank recalled from Command.

Many new Battalions arrived in camp direct from Canada during the month. A high rate of sickness developed amongst these new arrivals due largely to the unaccustomed dampness of the English climate.
1 Other Rank recalled from Command.
Number of patients in excess of bed capacity of Hospital temporarily accommodated on mattresses on floor etc.
Authority received from A.D.M.S. Brighton to use ward in Seaside Convalescent Hospital SEAFORD as auxiliary.
8 Other Ranks recalled from Command.
“Southlands” and “Hawkswick” buildings near Raven’s Croft Hospital taken over as auxiliary Hospitals for infectious cases. Bed capacity of each building approximately 50.
11 Other Ranks recalled from Command.
2 Other Ranks struck off Strength on discharge to Canada as medically unfit.
Average Number of Patients during month—200. (Canadian Military Hospital
Personnel present at date:- OFFICERS 6; NURSING SISTERS 6; OTHER RANKS 47.
Few cases of Cerebro-Spinal Meningitis developed amongst patients in Hospital.
Hospital and Staff placed under Quarantine. Cultures taken of all patients and personnel in Hospital.
Cultures of whole staff proved negative. Quarantine lifted.

Authority received for Unit to take over All Saints’ Hospital EASTBOURNE re-named Canadian Military Hospital EASTBOURNE. Same to be used as Headquarters of Unit and Central Hospital. Raven’s Croft Hawkswick and Southlands Hospitals SEAFORD to be retained as auxiliaries.
Major C. BROWN (C.A.D.C.) ceases to be attached on posting to BRAMSHOTT AREA.

Canadian Military Hospital EASTBOURNE composed of two large substantial brick buildings formerly occupied as a Church of England Convalescent Home and Annex. Total estimated bed capacity - 500. At this date Hospital was not equipped with Surgical X-Ray or Pathological apparatus. Advices from Director of Medical Services state that it is the intention to treat Overseas Casualties in this Hospital as soon as fully equipped.
